message: Xeno-canto API v2 will be phased out on October 10, 2025. Visit https://xeno-canto.org/explore/api for API v3 documentation.

recordings.loc: Toigil'dy, Buinsky District, Republic of Tatarstan

recordings.rmk: A nice sequence of type D social calls: part B-C, part A-B, part B, part B, part A-B-C, part B-E, part B-C and part B-C.

recordings.loc: San Marcos, San Marcos, Departamento de Ocotepeque

recordings.rmk:
Species identification by Wildlife Acoustics Echo Meter app build-in Auto-ID feature.


Highpass filter up to 10 000 Hz to mute the conversation.
The recording is original, vegetation type among large oak trees and meadows
Recordings of the Batu during the night hours among large oak trees and meadows. The bats have not been seen close up but seen frequently when hunting.
Species identification by Wildlife Acoustics Echo Meter app build-in Auto-ID feature.

Since this is a field recording it is not possible to be 100% sure it is a *Myotis brandtii* but it is much more likely than *M. mystacinus*.  
Recorded in a small clearing in a forest close to water. 

SNR: 73 dB (ISO/ITU)
recordings.dvc: Wildlife Acoustics Song meter mini bat

recordings.rmk:
This individual has ring number BA0468. 
The sound of a single tap on the microphone marks when it just had set off. 

Recorded on an open space outside a building, surrounded by birch forest.
[SNR 51dB(ISO/ITU) @t/10](https://xeno-canto.org/article/275)

Probably social calls, heard at one more occasion during the night, and also in one of the following nights.
Recorded while spotlighting. Animal was seen flying around in the area. Species was confirmed by the local guide whom is familiar with bat research.

recordings.loc: Sungai Penuh, Sungai Penuh City, Jambi
recordings.rmk:
Mystery bats flying around at dawn. See pictures here: https://observation.org/observation/334946848/

On the recording you can hear two species. I believe the lower ones might be Tadarida/Chaeropon. But what group does the higher one belong to? The seemed to have a roost underneath a roof on the outskirts of the town. Foraging over the rice fields in the valley between to rigdges of the Sumatran highlands.

Edit: changed to Saccolaimus saccolaimus, which is likely the species with which this recordings starts thanks to the remarks of Arjan Boonman. This one I did not see, but only heard live in the field.

recordings.loc: Klein Paradijs - Tuinontwerp (near  Hoenderloo), Apeldoorn, Gelderland
recordings.rmk: Social call of a common pipistrelle recorded while counting the number of bats visibly hibernating through ventilation cavities of a building. A flashlight was used. More than 30 individual bats were counted. It is likely that a way bigger number is present within the building.

Type D social calls of the common pipistrelle. Possibly an advertising bat.

recordings.loc: Spring Creek Reserve, Kiama, New South Wales
recordings.rmk: Calls from a colony
Calling from inside evergreen forest along Jimbe Stream. Loud monotonous calling throughout night(s) but notice interesting accelerations in this recording
Original recording, no editing. Chirps of Dwarf Galago (Thomas's or undescribed). Animal heard on multiple nights between 27 Sep and 14 Oct, with 4 or more males calling 13-14 Oct.
Probably same individual as in XC842426, but with different rythme

recordings.loc: Tongod District (near  Kinabatangan), Bahagian Sandakan, Sabah
recordings.rmk: Roost of several specimens under a building, both social calls as well as echolocation. One specimen photographed showed all the features of Rh. acuminatus. The photos will be placed here: https://observation.org/observation/285825747/. Sonograms seem to confirm this identifcation, being slightly higher and shorter compared to Rh. borneensis

recordings.loc: Keningau District (near  Keningau), Bahagian Pedalaman, Sabah
recordings.rmk: Calls of the bat when it flew around the photography hide that was its day-roost, just before it left. Also photographed to confirm the ID. See here https://observation.org/observation/286354922/

P. macrotis recorded in an open cenote with rainforest in the surroundings. The recorder (audiomoth) was installed near the water body (thus some refelections or 'shadows' can be seen in the pulses) 2 meters above ground. This recording is a part of a bigger data set of a passive acoustic monitoring project of my bachelor's thesis.

S. bilineata recorded in an open cenote with rainforest in the surroundings. The recorder (audiomoth) was installed near the water body (thus some refelections or 'shadows' can be seen in the pulses) 2 meters above ground. Low frequency and high frequency pulses can be seen in an alternating pattern. This recording is a part of a bigger data set of a passive acoustic monitoring project of my bachelor's thesis.

recordings.loc: Hoà Hải, Ngũ Hành Sơn, Đà Nẵng
recordings.rmk: Not modified. Uploaded at original speed. Stretch by 0.25 to appreciate the call. The bat was recorded soon after emerging from the cave where they have a roost of about 200 bats. The bat in question was actively feeding and visible. Its chirps are audible to unaided ear. The bat is small, about the size of sparrow. In good healthy condition, with shiny rich fur. The colony looked very dense and pretty healthy as well. There was little background noise except some insects.

recordings.rmk: M. alvarezi recorded emerging from roost (an abondoned warehouse) in the city of Merida, Mexico. Some individuals of M. nigricans were observed roosting. The recorder (Audiomoth) was installed 3 meters above ground in the backyard of a house close to the roost site. Low frequency and high frequency pulses can be seen in an alternating pattern.
25 kHz high-pass filter applied
20 kHz high-pass filter applied

M. nigircans recorded in an open gap of a deciduous rainforest, just in the external zone of a peten. The recorder (audiomoth) was installed on a tree 1.5 meters above ground. This recording is a part of a bigger data set of a passive acoustic monitoring project of my bachelor's thesis.
20 kHz high-pass filter applied
20 kHz high-pass filter applied
20 kHz high-pass filter applied
20 kHz high-pass filter applied

Bats were on a building's ceiling. Recordings were made right underneath the area where bats were roosting. Species was confirmed by capturing bats as they exited the roost. Bats started to exit the roost at 17:50. Bats started to return to the roost at ca. 20:30.

The recording contains multiple social calls and a feeding buzz.

I currently identify the echolocation calls with an end frequency of 20 kHz are the Brazilian free-tailed bat (Tadarida brasiliensis) and I suspect the echolocation calls with lower frequencies  to be Western bonneted bat (Eumops perotis).

In that case I'd name the social calls between 20,300s to 20,650s and between 25,200s to 25,550s to be from the Brazilian free-tailed bat and the social calls between 1,450s and 1,650s to be from the Western bonneted bat.


Used sources:

- https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/ecology-and-evolution/articles/10.3389/fevo.2019.00441/full
- https://www.scielo.br/j/rbzool/a/nsVBkCzyYkrhZZfSPsshrvF/?lang=en#
- https://www.researchgate.net/publication/255821856_Bats_of_the_State_of_Minas_Gerais_Southwestern_Brazil
- https://www.researchgate.net/publication/324708861_Who's_calling_Acoustic_identification_of_Brazilian_bats
- https://www.researchgate.net/publication/227630158_Individual_signatures_in_the_frequency-modulated_sweep_calls_of_African_large-eared_free-tailed_bats_Otomops_martiensseni_Chiroptera_Molossidae
- https://bioweb.bio/galeria/ListaEspeciesPorFamilia/2/157
- https://www.nps.gov/subjects/bats/echolocation.htm
- https://www.redalyc.org/journal/425/42547314019/html/

Bat trapped in garden, determined, ringed and recorded when released from hand.
Bat trapped in garden, determined, ringed and recorded when released from hand.

Walking stick shaped social calls, a bit faintly. They were recorded next to a park pond. A common pipistrelle with multiple two-component versions of it's type D social call are present in the recording aswell.

Two, that I would name, type B antagonistic social calls.

Marc van de Sijpe stated that he would be surprised if bursts of FM calls like these would have a sole echolocation function of prey approach and capture and that it would not be surprising if these calls are aggresive calls as a reaction to kleptoparasitism - when another animal wants to steal the prey (Neil Middleton, et al., 2022).

- Neil Middleton, Andrew Froud and Keith French (2022). Social Calls of the Bats of Britain and Ireland (second edition). Pelagic Publishing.
Huge and loud feeding buzz.

Two, that I would name, type B antagonistic social calls.

Marc van de Sijpe stated that he would be surprised if bursts of FM calls like these would have a sole echolocation function of prey approach and capture and that it would not be surprising if these calls are aggresive calls as a reaction to kleptoparasitism - when another animal wants to steal the prey (Neil Middleton, et al., 2022).

- Neil Middleton, Andrew Froud and Keith French (2022). Social Calls of the Bats of Britain and Ireland (second edition). Pelagic Publishing.

Unsure about these calls, but due to their low frequency I'd assume these are social calls. There was echolocation of pond bats recorded before and after this recording. About 25 minutes later, a foraging Nathusius' pipistrelle and pond bat type B social calls were recorded: XC920371.

Perhaps these are some sort of distress call of the pond bat, similar to the two examples on page 183 of the book "Bat Calls of Britain and Europe" edited by Jon Russ. But that is just a theory.

Type B social calls of a pond bat. They are very similar to the approach fase of a feeding buzz. This "feeding buzz" was recorded later that evening and shows a lot of similarity: XC920367

Marc van de Sijpe stated that he would be surprised if bursts of FM calls like these would have a sole echolocation function of prey approach and capture and that it would not be surprising if these calls are aggresive calls as a reaction to kleptoparasitism - when another animal wants to steal the prey (Neil Middleton, et al., 2022).

A Nathusius' pipistrelle with feeding buzzes is also present in the recording.

The recording XC920374 with unknown calls (possibly social calls of pond bat aswell) was made 25 minutes earlier on the same location.

- Neil Middleton, Andrew Froud and Keith French (2022). Social Calls of the Bats of Britain and Ireland (second edition). Pelagic Publishing.

A feeding buzz of a pond bat that does a little roller coaster: going down in frequeny, up in frequency and down again. It might be linked to these social calls that were recorded earlier on the evening: XC920371
One of the longest feeding buzzes of pond bat I've seen.
An extra long feeding buzz of a pond bat.
Clean recording of echolocation calls from a pond bat above water.
Very hockey-stick shaped echolocation calls of a pond bat.
Feeding buzz of a pond bat.
This recording was made when 425 individual pond bats were emerging from their maternity roost.
This recording was made when 425 individual pond bats were emerging from their maternity roost.
This recording was made when 425 individual pond bats were emerging from their maternity roost.
This recording was made when 425 individual pond bats were emerging from their maternity roost. Sadly, the recording is slightly glitched (repeating itself) in the beginning of the recording.

These type C social calls were recorded near a big waterway. It is believed to be a pond bat that was showing defensive behavior towards the Daubenton's bat whose echolocation is also present in the recording (Neil Middleton et. al., 2022, p. 148).
Clear feedingbuzz of a pond bat with very typically shaped echolocation calls.

recordings.rmk: Type C social calls of serotine bat in flight. The social calls have an upside-down U-shape and appear between 22,300 s and 27,200 s in the recording, with the exception of the social call in the middle that is mainly dropping down in frequency. The latter call is very similar to the serotine bat social call recorded by U. Marckmann, figure 8.7.1 in the book Social Calls of the Bats of Britain and Ireland by Neil Middleton, Andrew Froud and Keith French.
